context.p: To install Eucalyptus on servers running RHEL 5:

step.note: If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber, you should have received an rpm package file that you will need to install. If you are not a Eucalyptus subscriber, skip this step.

step.cmd: On all systems that will run either Eucalyptus or Euca2ools, run the following commands:
Enable the Cluster-Storage repository in Red Hat Network for each SC:

substep.cmd: Navigate to the system that will run the SC.
Make sure the RHEL Cluster Storage checkbox is checked.

step.cmd: Enable the Virtualization repository in Red Hat Network for each NC:

substep.cmd: On http://rhn.redhat.com, navigate to the system that will run the NC.
Make sure the RHEL Virtualization checkbox is checked.

step.cmd: If your planned Walrus server is running Xen (possible, but not recommended), install kmod-drbd83-xen package. Otherwise, skip this step.
Install Eucalyptus packages. The following example shows most components being installed all on the same server. You can use different servers for each component.

info.codeblock: yum groupinstall eucalyptus-cloud-controller yum install eucalyptus-cc eucalyptus-sc eucalyptus-walrus

step.cmd: On each planned NC server, install the NC package:

info.note: If you are using VMware, you can skip this step. Eucalyptus software is not installed on these machines. They are running VMware.

step.cmd: If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber and plan to use VMware, install the subscription only VMware Broker package on each CC. Otherwise, skip this step.
If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber and plan to use SAN support, install the enterprise only SAN package on each SC. Otherwise, skip this step.

taskbody.postreq: You are now ready to Configure Eucalyptus.
